00022 // This file contains compile-time configurations for Grbl's internal system. For the most part,
00023 // users will not need to directly modify these, but they are here for specific needs, i.e.
00024 // performance tuning or adjusting to non-typical machines.
00025 
00026 // IMPORTANT: Any changes here requires a full re-compiling of the source code to propagate them.
00027 
00028 #ifndef config_h
00029 #define config_h
00030 
00031 // Default settings. Used when resetting EEPROM. Change to desired name in defaults.h
00032 #define DEFAULTS_SHERLINE_5400
00033 
00034 // Serial baud rate
00035 #define BAUD_RATE 115200
00036 
00037 // Default cpu mappings. Grbl officially supports the Arduino Uno only. Other processor types
00038 // may exist from user-supplied templates or directly user-defined in cpu_map.h
00039 //#define CPU_MAP_ATMEGA328P // Arduino Uno CPU
00040 #define CPU_MAP_ATMEGA2560  // Arduino Mega2560r3
00041 
00042 // Define runtime command special characters. These characters are 'picked-off' directly from the
00043 // serial read data stream and are not passed to the grbl line execution parser. Select characters
00044 // that do not and must not exist in the streamed g-code program. ASCII control characters may be
00045 // used, if they are available per user setup. Also, extended ASCII codes (>127), which are never in
00046 // g-code programs, maybe selected for interface programs.
00047 // NOTE: If changed, manually update help message in report.c.
00048 #define CMD_STATUS_REPORT '?'
00049 #define CMD_FEED_HOLD '!'
00050 #define CMD_CYCLE_START '~'
00051 #define CMD_RESET 0x18 // ctrl-x.
00052 
00053 // If homing is enabled, homing init lock sets Grbl into an alarm state upon power up. This forces
00054 // the user to perform the homing cycle (or override the locks) before doing anything else. This is
00055 // mainly a safety feature to remind the user to home, since position is unknown to Grbl.
00056 #define HOMING_INIT_LOCK // Comment to disable
00057 
00058 // Define the homing cycle patterns with bitmasks. The homing cycle first performs a search mode
00059 // to quickly engage the limit switches, followed by a slower locate mode, and finished by a short
00060 // pull-off motion to disengage the limit switches. The following HOMING_CYCLE_x defines are executed
00061 // in order starting with suffix 0 and completes the homing routine for the specified-axes only. If
00062 // an axis is omitted from the defines, it will not home, nor will the system update its position.
00063 // Meaning that this allows for users with non-standard cartesian machines, such as a lathe (x then z,
00064 // with no y), to configure the homing cycle behavior to their needs.
00065 // NOTE: The homing cycle is designed to allow sharing of limit pins, if the axes are not in the same
00066 // cycle, but this requires some pin settings changes in cpu_map.h file. For example, the default homing
00067 // cycle can share the Z limit pin with either X or Y limit pins, since they are on different cycles.
00068 // By sharing a pin, this frees up a precious IO pin for other purposes. In theory, all axes limit pins
00069 // may be reduced to one pin, if all axes are homed with seperate cycles, or vice versa, all three axes
00070 // on separate pin, but homed in one cycle. Also, it should be noted that the function of hard limits
00071 // will not be affected by pin sharing.
00072 // NOTE: Defaults are set for a traditional 3-axis CNC machine. Z-axis first to clear, followed by X & Y.
00073 #define HOMING_CYCLE_0 (1<<Z_AXIS)                // REQUIRED: First move Z to clear workspace.
00074 #define HOMING_CYCLE_1 ((1<<X_AXIS)|(1<<Y_AXIS))  // OPTIONAL: Then move X,Y at the same time.
00075 // #define HOMING_CYCLE_2                         // OPTIONAL: Uncomment and add axes mask to enable
00076 
00077 // Number of homing cycles performed after when the machine initially jogs to limit switches.
00078 // This help in preventing overshoot and should improve repeatability. This value should be one or
00079 // greater.
00080 #define N_HOMING_LOCATE_CYCLE 2 // Integer (1-128)
00081 
00082 // Number of blocks Grbl executes upon startup. These blocks are stored in EEPROM, where the size
00083 // and addresses are defined in settings.h. With the current settings, up to 3 startup blocks may
00084 // be stored and executed in order. These startup blocks would typically be used to set the g-code
00085 // parser state depending on user preferences.
00086 #define N_STARTUP_LINE 2 // Integer (1-3)
00087 
00088 // Allows GRBL to tranck and report gcode line numbers.  Enabling this means that the planning buffer
00089 // goes from 18 or 16 to make room for the additional line number data in the plan_block_t struct
00090 // #define USE_LINE_NUMBERS // Disabled by default. Uncomment to enable.
00091 
00092 // Enables a second coolant control pin via the mist coolant g-code command M7 on the Arduino Uno
00093 // analog pin 5. Only use this option if you require a second coolant control pin.
00094 // NOTE: The M8 flood coolant control pin on analog pin 4 will still be functional regardless.
00095 // #define ENABLE_M7 // Disabled by default. Uncomment to enable.
00096 
00097 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
00098 // ADVANCED CONFIGURATION OPTIONS:
00099 
00100 // The temporal resolution of the acceleration management subsystem. A higher number gives smoother
00101 // acceleration, particularly noticeable on machines that run at very high feedrates, but may negatively
00102 // impact performance. The correct value for this parameter is machine dependent, so it's advised to
00103 // set this only as high as needed. Approximate successful values can widely range from 50 to 200 or more.
00104 // NOTE: Changing this value also changes the execution time of a segment in the step segment buffer.
00105 // When increasing this value, this stores less overall time in the segment buffer and vice versa. Make
00106 // certain the step segment buffer is increased/decreased to account for these changes.
00107 #define ACCELERATION_TICKS_PER_SECOND 100
00108 
00109 // Adaptive Multi-Axis Step Smoothing (AMASS) is an advanced feature that does what its name implies,
00110 // smoothing the stepping of multi-axis motions. This feature smooths motion particularly at low step
00111 // frequencies below 10kHz, where the aliasing between axes of multi-axis motions can cause audible
00112 // noise and shake your machine. At even lower step frequencies, AMASS adapts and provides even better
00113 // step smoothing. See stepper.c for more details on the AMASS system works.
00114 #define ADAPTIVE_MULTI_AXIS_STEP_SMOOTHING  // Default enabled. Comment to disable.
00115 
00116 // Enables variable spindle output voltage for different RPM values. On the Arduino Uno, the spindle
00117 // enable pin will output 5V for maximum RPM with 256 intermediate levels and 0V when disabled.
00118 // NOTE: IMPORTANT for Arduino Unos! When enabled, the Z-limit pin D11 and spindle enable pin D12 switch!
00119 // The hardware PWM output on pin D11 is required for variable spindle output voltages.
00120 // #define VARIABLE_SPINDLE // Default disabled. Uncomment to enable.
00121 
00122 // Use by the variable spindle output only. These parameters set the maximum and minimum spindle speed
00123 // "S" g-code values to correspond to the maximum and minimum pin voltages. There are 256 discrete and
00124 // equally divided voltage bins between the maximum and minimum spindle speeds. So for a 5V pin, 1000
00125 // max rpm, and 250 min rpm, the spindle output voltage would be set for the following "S" commands:
00126 // "S1000" @ 5V, "S250" @ 0.02V, and "S625" @ 2.5V (mid-range). The pin outputs 0V when disabled.
00127 #define SPINDLE_MAX_RPM 1000.0 // Max spindle RPM. This value is equal to 100% duty cycle on the PWM.
00128 #define SPINDLE_MIN_RPM 0.0    // Min spindle RPM. This value is equal to (1/256) duty cycle on the PWM.
00129 
00130 // Minimum planner junction speed. Sets the default minimum junction speed the planner plans to at
00131 // every buffer block junction, except for starting from rest and end of the buffer, which are always
00132 // zero. This value controls how fast the machine moves through junctions with no regard for acceleration
00133 // limits or angle between neighboring block line move directions. This is useful for machines that can't
00134 // tolerate the tool dwelling for a split second, i.e. 3d printers or laser cutters. If used, this value
00135 // should not be much greater than zero or to the minimum value necessary for the machine to work.
00136 #define MINIMUM_JUNCTION_SPEED 0.0 // (mm/min)
00137 
00138 // Number of arc generation iterations by small angle approximation before exact arc trajectory
00139 // correction. This parameter maybe decreased if there are issues with the accuracy of the arc
00140 // generations. In general, the default value is more than enough for the intended CNC applications
00141 // of grbl, and should be on the order or greater than the size of the buffer to help with the
00142 // computational efficiency of generating arcs.
00143 // NOTE: Arcs are now generated by a chordal tolerance
00144 #define N_ARC_CORRECTION 20 // Integer (1-255)
00145 
00146 // Time delay increments performed during a dwell. The default value is set at 50ms, which provides
00147 // a maximum time delay of roughly 55 minutes, more than enough for most any application. Increasing
00148 // this delay will increase the maximum dwell time linearly, but also reduces the responsiveness of
00149 // run-time command executions, like status reports, since these are performed between each dwell
00150 // time step. Also, keep in mind that the Arduino delay timer is not very accurate for long delays.
00151 #define DWELL_TIME_STEP 50 // Integer (1-255) (milliseconds)
00152 
00153 // Creates a delay between the direction pin setting and corresponding step pulse by creating
00154 // another interrupt (Timer2 compare) to manage it. The main Grbl interrupt (Timer1 compare)
00155 // sets the direction pins, and does not immediately set the stepper pins, as it would in
00156 // normal operation. The Timer2 compare fires next to set the stepper pins after the step
00157 // pulse delay time, and Timer2 overflow will complete the step pulse, except now delayed
00158 // by the step pulse time plus the step pulse delay. (Thanks langwadt for the idea!)
00159 // NOTE: Uncomment to enable. The recommended delay must be > 3us, and, when added with the
00160 // user-supplied step pulse time, the total time must not exceed 127us. Reported successful
00161 // values for certain setups have ranged from 5 to 20us.
00162 // #define STEP_PULSE_DELAY 10 // Step pulse delay in microseconds. Default disabled.
00163 
00164 // The number of linear motions in the planner buffer to be planned at any give time. The vast
00165 // majority of RAM that Grbl uses is based on this buffer size. Only increase if there is extra
00166 // available RAM, like when re-compiling for a Mega or Sanguino. Or decrease if the Arduino
00167 // begins to crash due to the lack of available RAM or if the CPU is having trouble keeping
00168 // up with planning new incoming motions as they are executed.
00169 // #define BLOCK_BUFFER_SIZE 18  // Uncomment to override default in planner.h.
00170 
00171 // Governs the size of the intermediary step segment buffer between the step execution algorithm
00172 // and the planner blocks. Each segment is set of steps executed at a constant velocity over a
00173 // fixed time defined by ACCELERATION_TICKS_PER_SECOND. They are computed such that the planner
00174 // block velocity profile is traced exactly. The size of this buffer governs how much step
00175 // execution lead time there is for other Grbl processes have to compute and do their thing
00176 // before having to come back and refill this buffer, currently at ~50msec of step moves.
00177 // #define SEGMENT_BUFFER_SIZE 6 // Uncomment to override default in stepper.h.
00178 
00179 // Line buffer size from the serial input stream to be executed. Also, governs the size of
00180 // each of the startup blocks, as they are each stored as a string of this size. Make sure
00181 // to account for the available EEPROM at the defined memory address in settings.h and for
00182 // the number of desired startup blocks.
00183 // NOTE: 70 characters is not a problem except for extreme cases, but the line buffer size
00184 // can be too small and g-code blocks can get truncated. Officially, the g-code standards
00185 // support up to 256 characters. In future versions, this default will be increased, when
00186 // we know how much extra memory space we can re-invest into this.
00187 // #define LINE_BUFFER_SIZE 70  // Uncomment to override default in protocol.h
00188 
00189 // Serial send and receive buffer size. The receive buffer is often used as another streaming
00190 // buffer to store incoming blocks to be processed by Grbl when its ready. Most streaming
00191 // interfaces will character count and track each block send to each block response. So,
00192 // increase the receive buffer if a deeper receive buffer is needed for streaming and avaiable
00193 // memory allows. The send buffer primarily handles messages in Grbl. Only increase if large
00194 // messages are sent and Grbl begins to stall, waiting to send the rest of the message.
00195 // #define RX_BUFFER_SIZE 128 // Uncomment to override defaults in serial.h
00196 // #define TX_BUFFER_SIZE 64
00197 
00198 // Toggles XON/XOFF software flow control for serial communications. Not officially supported
00199 // due to problems involving the Atmega8U2 USB-to-serial chips on current Arduinos. The firmware
00200 // on these chips do not support XON/XOFF flow control characters and the intermediate buffer
00201 // in the chips cause latency and overflow problems with standard terminal programs. However,
00202 // using specifically-programmed UI's to manage this latency problem has been confirmed to work.
00203 // As well as, older FTDI FT232RL-based Arduinos(Duemilanove) are known to work with standard
00204 // terminal programs since their firmware correctly manage these XON/XOFF characters. In any
00205 // case, please report any successes to grbl administrators!
00206 // #define ENABLE_XONXOFF // Default disabled. Uncomment to enable.
00207 
00208 // A simple software debouncing feature for hard limit switches. When enabled, the interrupt
00209 // monitoring the hard limit switch pins will enable the Arduino's watchdog timer to re-check
00210 // the limit pin state after a delay of about 32msec. This can help with CNC machines with
00211 // problematic false triggering of their hard limit switches, but it WILL NOT fix issues with
00212 // electrical interference on the signal cables from external sources. It's recommended to first
00213 // use shielded signal cables with their shielding connected to ground (old USB/computer cables
00214 // work well and are cheap to find) and wire in a low-pass circuit into each limit pin.
00215 // #define ENABLE_SOFTWARE_DEBOUNCE // Default disabled. Uncomment to enable.
00216 
00217 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

00225 // #error Parameters ACCELERATION_TICKS / ISR_TICKS must be < 256 to prevent integer overflow.
